por.por_cntn:
In this project, the PI considered several problems whose solutions have shed
considerable light upon the interplay between “harmonic measure”, and geometry,
using techniques of Harmonic Analysis and Geometric Measure Theory. Let
me begin with a discussion of the meaning of these terms, suitable for the nonspecialist.
Roughly speaking, in Harmonic Analysis one investigates properties of functions
(one might think of functions in terms of their pictorial representation as
curves or surfaces) and “operators” (i.e., mappings which transform one function,
or curve or surface, into another) by decomposing them into smaller, constituent
pieces, which are easier to understand, and then reassembling the pieces. The name
itself arose by analogy to the decomposition of a musical sound into its various frequency
components, or “harmonics”.
“Harmonic measure” can be understood as follows. Consider the propagation of
heat through a fluid in a container. Heat is conducted through the fluid by the transfer
of kinetic energy (the energy possessed by an object in motion) from molecule
to molecule. A particle suspended in the fluid will be buffeted by these molecular
collisions, causing it to move along a random path. This phenomenon, the theory
of which was developed in large part by Einstein in 1905, is referred to as Brownian
motion. Now let us fix some specified point P inside the container (that is
within the fluid), and imagine a region (let’s call it “R”) on the inner surface of
the container. The harmonic measure at P, of the region R, is just the probability
that a “Brownian traveler” starting from P eventually reaches the region R before
it touches any other part of the container surface.
Thus, the harmonic measure at any given point P describes the ease or difficulty
with which heat can communicate between P and the region R. Therefore it serves
to convey geometric information about the shape of the container: if the harmonic
measure at P, of a region R, is relatively small, it means that Brownian travelers
coming from P are somewhat “screened” from R by other portions of the surface of
the container, and this in turn implies that the container must be rather irregular in
shape. On the other hand, if the container is a perfectly round ball, then a Brownian
traveler starting from the center of the ball is equally likely to end up anywhere on
the surface of the container.
Not surprisingly, this circle of ideas has many practical applications, and not
just to matters of heat conduction. For example, there is recent work in acoustical
engineering in which an understanding of harmonic measure has been used to help
design a room with desirable acoustic properties: say, with sound emitted from one
area focussed in certain receiving regions, or for that matter screened from certain
regions.
The principle goal of this project was to understand in quantitatively precise
ways the relationship between harmonic measure and geometry, using tools of harmonic
analysis.
